reviewText:
Early Access Review

ChroniconDeveloper: Subworld
Publisher: Subworld

Note: A key for this game was provided by the developer for the purpose of writing an informative review. No other compensation was given.

Introduction
==========
Chronicon is about a special magical device...a device that creates a link to the memories of the long-forgotten heroes of yore. A link that allows anyone who ventures forth to relive the past lives of those fallen heroes. You are chosen as one of the few this time...and being chosen is a great honor. What will you do now?

Chronicon is an action-adventure RPG, set in a (so far) small, Early Access world. Yes, Chronicon is in Early Access, but if you look past that tag, you might see the potential Chronicon has. Let's take a peek at what it has in store for you.

Gameplay
==========
So you've installed Chronicon and hit Play Game. You are greeted with a selection of 4 unique heroes: Templar, Berserker, Warden, and Warlock. Each one has a very distinct playstyle. The Templar and Berserker are melee characters, the difference being the Templar is defensive and the Berkserker is offensive. The Warden and Warlock are ranged, with their difference being physical offense (bow/arrows) and magical offense. Choose whichever playstyle suits you the best!

Each character has a small 'tree' of skills they can learn and assign to be used on the fly. You can access a new tier of skills every 5 levels. As you level up by killing monsters you gain skill points (1 per level), and you can invest these points into the skills of your choosing. The more points you invest into a particular skill, the more powerful or effective it becomes. Each character has unique skills and passives that can be learned, some offering great benefits, others offering new spells and actions.

At it's core, Chronicon is a dungeon crawler, similar to titles such as Diablo, Torchlight, or Titan's Quest. You explore a locale, kill monsters, collect loot, and level up. There are even some features in Chronicon that you may recall seeing in these other titles, such as the Portal Scroll which gives you a ticket back to the hub to sell your loot. There are also Waypoints, which you can use to traveI back and forth between predetermined points in each area. Speaking of areas, in the hub there are 5 Teleport Orbs, each one representing a dungeon/location. Only the Fallen Temple (first orb) is currently available, and during my 7-8 hours of play none of the other orbs were made available. The Store Page says these additional levels are coming in future updates. I played Chronicon with a controller, and the combat reminded me of a twin stick shooter. You move your character with the left stick, and aim your attacks with the right stick. It works, to be sure, but it was a little awkward for me at first to see this kind of control scheme in a game of this particular genre.

There are a lot of breakable objects, such as pots, urns, and baskets. These can be great for finding hidden loot and crystals (currency) but I felt like they served to padden the game a little bit. There are literally TONS of breakable objects in each stage, but only small groups of enemies scattered through each stage. I would much rather have mowed through hordes of enemies than break a room full of pots. This might be attributed to the fact that the game is still in Early Access, so I was able to look past it. When you did find monsters, it was fun to mow them down however you could, occasionally enjoying a slightly more prolonged encounter with a 'champion' monster. These are quite a bit more powerful than the normal monsters, and drop significantly more loot. Also spread throughout are small shrines, which take the form of statues. When activated, they may give you a buff or heal you, but they can also rarely spawn powerful creatures to attack you.

Certain loot can only be used by certain classes, and a lot of loot has its own special qualities. An item of one type can be very different than another item of the same type, depending on the quality. Try to stay outfitted with the best gear possible for the best chance of survival!

Graphics
==========
Chronicon has a very distinct sprite-base design. They aren't what I'd call 'basic', but they aren't too terribly detailed either. Don't get me wrong, they look great for sprites, and animations are crisp, clear, and flow smoothly. But don't expect anything special as you play.

The Fallen Temple looked really good...very dark and creepy, as something 'fallen' should be! The monsters fit the theme of the area...ghouls, skeletons, and ghosts running around everywhere. Even some bats thrown in for good measure. All of these have the same quality as the character sprites, and are animated pretty well.

Sound and Music
==========
This is easily the game's biggest downside. There is very little in the way of music or sound effects. The Fallen Temple has a low, somber tune that plays, but that's about it. Your attacks, breaking pots and urns, and hitting enemies have sound effects. But nothing else does. If it did, I hardly noticed. I also attribute this to the game being Early Access, so I was able to overlook it. Understanding that this is a very early Alpha build means that not all assets are implemented yet, and I'm sure they will be in the future!

Performance
==========
Chronicon ran without any hitches on my medium-tier rig. It should pose no issues to most players. It's not a very intense game, and I don't expect many people to run into any performance issues. Does your kitchen have a toaster? It can probably run Chronicon.

I played entirely with a controller, so I can confirm that it indeed has full controller support. The controls were very easy for me to use, even with the twin stick configuration combat has.

Final Thoughts
==========
At the end of the day, Chronicon is a decent entry into the action-adventure RPG genre. It's by no means the best, but it's not terrible. It's worth checking out and at least keeping an eye on as it develops further. With a handful of playable classes, lots of loot to collect, and small hordes of enemies to mow down, you should have a great time exploring the memories of past heroes. Future updates plan to include crafting, more quests, more items, a hardcore mode, and the 4 additional chapters currently missing from the hub. If you want to help this game out and see it suceed, please, by all means give it a purchase to support the devs! This is what Early Access is all about.

Gameplay Demo
==========
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RuQ2o68_PDM

Nerd House Verdict:
==========
Recommended

Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So much death. So much loot. So much fun.

Seriously, this game is a blast. A Stone. Cold. Blast. I got it for the positive reviews, thought I'd pop in for ten minutes (like I do with most newly purchased games) and then move onto my usual game of the day. Well, over two hours later, I came up for air in something of a state of bliss.

This game gives the carrot and stick perfectly. It's like Diablo 3 in that regard. One more dungeon for that one more piece of loot that'll give you better stats. There's so much loot its insane. The review that said to learn not to pick up everything ain't kidding. Slots are very limited, so you really have to curate what you want.

I've only planed one class, but I can't wait to play more. I mean four classes each with four skill trees? That's pretty awesome. So far, I'm just having a blast, and if you like fast-paced, loot-filled dungeon crawlers, you will too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game brought back memories of diablo 2. Lets make a list..
-Loot-Tons of it, and so much breakable items it makes you sick, as well as chests, Sets and Legendary Items as well!!
-Mobs- Normal, Champions, And Bosses..
-Char Progression- You level as you go, and gain access to skill trees, 4 per char. Wish there was attribute points but that is what gear choices are for.
-Health and Mana pots galore and you use them, keeps you busy. Also potions for buffs
-Secret areas that contain more loot
-Gambling!!
-Waypoints
-Even some of the sounds are similiar to diablo 2 :)
-Zones are MASSIVE and you can spend hours in them
-You will go to town a lot to sale loot so keep portal scrolls with you!!

This is going to be a fantastic dungeon crawler when completed, although there is much work needed it is very polished at its current state.

Recommend to any ARPG enthusiast that loves to loot and level.
Haven't tried Coop yet but can only imagine how fun that could be.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Chronicon is essentially an indie version of Diablo, and I really like it. You can play up to four players local (no online), which really spices things up with a game like this. I was never too keen on Diablo, but this I can get into - especially with a friend or two.

If you are not familiar with the Diablo series or type of gameplay, it basically consists of action-based hack-n-slash dungeon crawling to 1) gain experience, and 2) pick up loot, which is hopefully better than what you have. Then you return to a main hub or town to manage your stuff and level up. Rinse and repeat. Its a simple formula, but can be quite addictive and really offer tons of replayability, especially considering different hero classes.

Pros:
+Graphics are nice
+Up to four players local
+Full controller support
+Totally cheap for the amount of replayability
+Lots of great in-game options for things like map placement/opacity, text size, lighting options, and tons more - I really appreciate this for a game that you can play from the couch with four people (in the past, there are a few games that would have been totally great if it weren't for limited options like this)

Meh:
=Music is decent so far

Cons:
-We need to get more people following this game - the community is super small
-Its not done yet - which is almost never a 'Con' for me, but its one guy and I just really hope this title gets finished to the point of the original vision.

Yeah, if you like Diablo and you like indie games - this is totally worth full price, IMO.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wow, this is a seriously fun loot filled RPG, and its so cheap.

I have tried most new loot fest type RPG's that have a similar play style to Diablo/TQ over the last couple of years and this game is one of the most fun out of the whole lot. Chronicon just gets things it so right.

The current video (Updte 0.40.0) really does well to show what this game is capable of and how you can take your champ/build too amazing heights.

The upcoming changes in update 0.50.0 just make this game even more worth while, with even more gear slots/options and in turn more ability to play with getting your stats setup just right.

Sure the skill tree is no where near as complex as PoE and the visuals are not as nice as D3, but so far this game is an epic 10/10 and shines bright alongside much bigger titles, and there is still more to come from a really friendly and active Developer. I cant wait to see how this game progresses while it moves through early access and onto full release.

I onlyhave two gripes about the game so far:
- Can't move and attack at the same time (This may be a good thing)
- Very limited multiplayer

TLDR: Really fun loot filled RPG, worth far more than it costs. 10/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fun action rpg of the Diablo/Torchlight variety with nostalgic graphics, random dungeons, lots of loot, and 4 distinct classes. Slightly clunky, but very well-developed for an early access title.

For maximum enjoyment: use a controller, turn up the ambient light in the settings, find a big screen, and invite three friends with three more controllers.

Edit: Having now played Chronicon for over 60 hours and reached level cap, I thought it worthwhile to expand this review.

Chronicon is easily one of the best Early Access titles I've played. The game is well balanced, the classes are already fleshed-out (with 4 skills trees each and plenty of legendaries to enhance each tree), and the level design is random enough that there's always an element of uncertainty (although the very small maps tend to just juggle around enemy variety and placement). The game has pretty solid controller support for both XBox 360 and Steam Controller; I mostly play with the latter.

The local co-op is one of Chronicon's strongest features. I've played a few hours with my brother and my girlfriend and it's a really enjoyable and straighforward experience. Just plug in another controller and go. Be prepared to spend a fair bit of downtown sorting through loot, though.

The updates have been very regular and significant so far. I worry about the amount of sleep the dev is getting. Bug fixes come very quickly and I haven't yet encountered a bug that ruined the game or cost me significant progress.

The plot isn't particularly rivetting, but I've never played an ARPG with an even remotely engaging plot, so this doesn't bother me. We're all here to kill monsters, after all, not read walls of text. And Chronicon's monster-slaying is highly satisfying. This is a game where you butcher hundreds of enemies in one go. The game includes a killstreak mechanic similar to D3's, except in Chronicon you'll quickly find yourself bringing in killstreaks that break 100. On higher levels, you'll find yourself getting closer to 1000.

I highly recommend Chronicon, especially if you're a fan of loot-heavy, dungeon crawling action rpgs but miss the controller support of older console titles like Dark Alliance and Champions of Norrath.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A Diablo-like Action RPGhttps://youtu.be/5tur9hQaib8
+ Many hours worth of of content
+ Tons of loot to collect
+ A Good progression system where you level up and get better abilities for your character
+ A stash to share items between characters
+ Great variety of enemy types
+ Bosses are quite fun and rewarding to face
+ Quests with quite a bit of background lroe to them.
+ Lots of breakable objects WITH LOOT (Glares at Diablo 3 -.-)
+ Similar gear system as Diablo where items have a large variety of different modifiers that will effect your character and how you play, including rare Set items which have additional effects.
+ Great retro styled graphics and animations

This game is in EARLY ACCESS so don't take these negatives too seriously
- I felt like the inventory was far too small, you will fill up on items FAST, and it forces you to leave lots of stuff on the ground, and constantly check your bag and toss items to make room for others.
- It starts out quite slow having only 1 or 2 very basic abilities
- You can't move and fire or hit at the same time which can be frustrating at times.

~ There is local co-op, but this game would benefit greatly from multiplayer co-op (seriously if at all possible this needs to be added)

Definitely a great game for those who like action RPGs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well there isn't really much else to say that the other reviews haven't already said, but I will say that the game is very good. It's well made, with very good gameplay mechanics and surprisingly a lot to do. There isn't as much content as I would like, as of writing this review there is currently only 1 act available. However, don't let that fool you as there is a lot of content packed into the act, plus there are something like 5 different difficulties to choose from (though they dont really change things much).

The maps are giant, to do a full clear of a map will likely take at least an hour if not more to complete. There are tons of enemies and various enemy modifiers that can make enemies different, like speed modifiers and element modifiers. There are secret rooms packed with treasures, there are tons of items to find, with lots of various stats. There are currently 4 classes (a paladin (template), warrior (beserker), hunter (warden), mage (warlock)). Each class has 3 skill paths, 2 paths for active skills and 1 path for passive skills. Each class can have a total of 3 active skills at once, with the ability to reset your skills from a potion within town. Each skill can be upgraded a total of 10 times. There are pets and minions as well.

As it stands the game is really good, I can't wait for more content and updates. Something else worth noting is that the developer is very involved, posting and helping in the forums to every question asked so far. I really hope the game succeeds as i would love to see this game fully developed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While still in early access this game is nice hack'n'slack RPG that will satisfy your loot itch. The art style while definitely unique, it kinda feels a bit too simplistic for my taste but that doesn't take away from the fun. There's 3 Acts completed by the time of this review and the developer updates quite frequently with content and general fixes, there's 2 more acts in the works from what it seems which is quite exciting!

The combat might feel stiff at times but there's nothing too serious to hinder the player. There's lots of dungeons to explore, quests and optional quests, a quite decent story to unravel and the gear system is top notch. Legendaries, sets, you name it. There are several classes to choose from, each one with own specific talent tree and an important note is that you can actually change your talents at your leisure for dirt cheap.

There's some endgame content in the form of Anomalies (think of Diablo III rifts) and quite a few secrets within the main campaign.

Overall this is a very promising game, sort of like a diamond in the rough, quite worth its price compared to the hours of content provided, and there's replayability with playing different classes and doing anomalies. The game also supports local co-op however I did not had the chance to give it a go.

Recommended for experienced ARPG fans and even more so for those who might be new to genre.

As others have mentioned, this plays like a twin-stick Diablo. The limited lighting globe, especially, is reminiscent of Diablo 1. I found the game pleasant, and playable, but lacking a bit of depth or polish. One can see the charm oozing off it, and how the game will turn out to be. At present, this game is a pleasant 7/10. However, with a few months of polish, this game stands out to me as a 10/10 achievement.

P.S: A controller is recommended.

P.P.S: And, yes, the asking price is reasonable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My first review on Steam.

If you like Diablo 2 you will feel right at home with Chronicon.
Seriously, this game only gets better the more you play and the developer (yes, this is a ONE person made game) spews out updates like there’s no tomorrow. It´s a Hacknslash ARGP with tons of loot and randomization.
Act 3 is being worked on & A4 + A5 are coming. Even in this early state the game is amazingly fun.
Four classes might sound little but each has 4 different build trees, There are 100 levels available and more classes will eventually get released once the game goes live.
This is the story of how a 1-person indie developer can do better games than multimillion dollar companies. It´s David vs. Goliath and it´s all about passion. The itemzation alone is better than anything I’ve seen since D2. Yes, it´s not that pretty and yes it is old school 8-bit graphics - if Virtual Eye Candy is a must look elsewhere. For those who can accept lesser graphics for better game quality think Gauntlet meets Diablo 2 and immensely addictive.
Even the pricing is ridiculously low. 10 bucks? I threw more than double the price amount on donations alone just to get this going.


Cons
The build trees themselves could use more diversity
No online play
8 bit graphics
Needs more advertisement (WAKE UP Total Biscuit, Angry Joe, ReformistTM, Quill18 and all the others)

Pros
Old school ARGP at its finest
The developer clearly shows a lot of passion and it easy to get smitten
Keyboard or gamepad - your choice
Up to 4 Players on one machine with gamepads
Random maps
Quests
100 Class and skill point levels
Five difficulties (you choose difficulty each new session)
No-return portals with random zone affixes
Cheap Skill-reset potions
Legendary loot can drop from the get go
Shrines that yield buffs
Riddles yielding extra loot when solved
10 bucks
Tons of customization in the options menu
10 bucks
4 Trees with overlapping mechanics for each class
10 bucks

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game at it's core is an ARPG, and I'd compare it to gauntlet than any other game, other than the loot which is pretty damn good.

There are 4 classes, Templar, Berserker, Warden, and a Warlock.

Each class has two skill trees, and then one passive.

There are already unique and legendary items in this game which massively change skills or boost your stats, my favorite one is a bow that changes multishot into a split shot that splits into more arrows.

Controls need some rebinding when you pop in, but other than that the game is pretty dang smooth.


This is only an alpha right now but it feels like the dev could pass it off as a beta.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Chronicon is a promising 2.5D ARPG that features loads of loot, 4 classes, over 400 abilities, randomly generated worlds, and much, much more.

It's only being made by one guy, so development is slow. I would recommend this game at $15 or less. It may not compete with Diablo or the like just yet, but watch out for this game. It has enormous potential and unmistakable charm.

Pros and good qualities

+ Outstanding UI. Innovative and simple to use, fitting multiple menus together in a way I have never seen before.

+ Simple level design, and it randomly generates each time you re-enter a room

+ Chronicon follows the Diablo II formula to a T. You'll see everything from rolling text on NPCs, to shrines in the areas that boost your abilities for a short time. The game has all the makings of every successful ARPG.

Neutral things down to personal preference

+/- Limited inventory space and no ability to increase it. This makes you have to be careful about what you pick up, but the scarcity of storage is moot when you can just tp back to town and sell everything anyway.

+/- Basic combat. Nothing revolutionary in the way of combat, but decent and certainly playable.

+/- The visuals in this game aren't spectacular and may pull you out of the experience, depending on your taste. I feel fine with these visuals, they are pretty reminiscent of Terraria.

+/- Limited cosmetic gear. This may not bother everyone, but I find it a real issue that my Templar doesn't equip her helmet, or that there isn't at least an option to do so.

+/- 2.5D perspective

+/- Simple visuals

Cons and things that could be improved

- Lack of online co-op

- Lack of collision sounds when hitting enemies with a sword

- Needs more ADVERTISING to get this game a fanbase!

Seriously guys, pick this up. NOW.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Without a ton of hours put into this game, there's a few things I can tell you.

Firstly, if you're a fan of Diabloesque gameplay, Chronicon has got it. If you're into Indie games and the fresh perspective they bring, you'll like what you see. If you enjoy refreshingly lo-fi graphics that invoke the feeling of nostalgia, then you'll need to look no further. If seek an experience that constantly beckons you back for more, you'll be hooked. If you like loot, and lots of it, you'll have more than you need. If you find yourself attracted to Mobs, you'll be in good company. If you need a new RPG to scratch that fantasy itch, you'll find relief here. If you dig games that don't take themselves too seriously, the gameplay will put you at ease. Lastly, if you want mechanics that don't get in the way of fun, Chronicon will deliver it.

So yeah, give it a try. The price is right and if you hit on more than one item I touched on above, you surely won't regret it!

Its basically hero siege with a little bit of diablo. It is early access so maybe these things will be changed, but as of right now, its not fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Chronicon is the dungeon crawler I've been waiting my whole life for.

Pros:
-Tons of loot!
-Ultra-rare items make a very distinct noise when dropped, you will always notice them.
-Four classes to choose from.
-Each class has four skill trees, so there are plenty of ways to build them.
-Characters can be easily respecced and renamed.
-Plenty of item effects to help build your character (+poison damage, thorns, spell casts on hit, magic find, etc.)
-5 difficulty settings.
-Level ups happen often enough that your character always feels like it's progressing.
-Attractive pixel art. It's easy to make out what's happening even when things get crowded.

Cons:
-I wish I could adjust the map's opacity. (whoops, I didn't look hard enough)
-The skill trees could use a little more variety.

Early Access Review

A complete RPG diablo style game. Many enemies on the screen, blood and LOOT! So much LOOT! This game is very addictive, attractive and nifty. The environment music is dark, obscure and holds you. Combat system is fluid and easy to manage. The skill tree is very well made and gives you many possibilities to make your build in the way you want. I bought yesterday this early access game and I know for experience that this game is awesome. It seems the devs are very responsive and always has updates for the game. I totally recommend Chronicon. I hope in a near future a multiplayer lan game. I give 9/10.

Update after 13h game

I swear that I never played a game so rewarding before like this one. Every elite enemy or a badass boss always drop a high value item. You constantly changes your equipment on a higher level new one and because of this you'll never be tired of your current equipment set. I strongly recommend to play this game on a higher difficult....you won't regret it ;). Search every corner for a chest and enter in every portal to another dimension when appear it. It is very, VERY rewarding. After more than 13h of game I'm still in the 1st chapter. This game is absolutely HUGE. The skills after you leveling up becomes more and more awesome, you know that you are getting stronger. And damn....I love this felling in a game.

There is more loot than you know what to do with, each character has 4 skill trees each of them devoted to an element, the interface is very clean and easy to use, the animation and lighting is top notch, really excited to see where this game is going to end up.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAs far as loot goes its pretty good. Finding new items felt good.. But one of the biggest draws to this genre for me personally is the cosmetic side of things. Take Diablo 3 for example, being able to equip different gear and have it visibily change the look of my character is great! Plus they added transmog in which made it even better. I was disappointed to see that in Chronicon as soon as i started equipping things my character didnt change at all. Im fine with gender locked/base type characters in games like this, but having zero gear customization at all really kills any fun I had with it. I refunded the game for now, but hope maybe they are planning to add more customization once they have the core fundamentals of the game nailed down first. If not, its a pass as there are much better games in the same genre that have everything it offers plus more.

What are you doing? Get out of the negative review section.

Strongly recommend this game. I torrented this game and played it for probably 50 hours, and was so antsy for the new updates that I bought it at full price. (I usually torrent and wait for a flash sale). The new updates are bloody fantastic.

If I was to label this game, I'd call it a 2D sprite-based Diablo.

I only have one complaint, and that's that this game only has local co-op (Up to 4 players) while I'd like to have LAN multiplayer. The developer is very active though and I think it's on the todo list. This developer releases new versions in 'chunks' with major updates coming every now and then, and they always strongly enhance the quality of the game.

This game currently is an 8/10 with those numbers likely going higher in subsequent versions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access Review

Well, early days yet for this game, and it's made by one guy, though despite this it shows much promise. However, I give it my recommendation because of this, and in spite of it's various flaws.

The skill system could use some work. A lot of it is cookie-cutter. Main Skill + Mana Reducing effect. I am not exageratting when I say every class follows this path, so the early hours of the game are mainly spamming a single skill. And why do I need to dump 10 skill points into that skill for it be usable? I should be spending those points on getting new abilities which will vary the game play.

The combat, outside of character building, is simple, but satisfying. Screen shakes, enemies explode all over the place, kill chains keep you moving (would love the timer bar from D3 in there!). That's all good stuff.

The itemization is also fairly solid, with some neat items to find, and while nothing mind blowing or game changing, there is a certain level of character customization to be found in what gear you decide to wear. Healing vs. Damage vs. Utility.

I give it a tentative recommendation. I will probably keep an eye out and keep playing, but hopefully over time, the skill system could get a closer look to enable more varied combat between classes and skill trees.

There is some stiff competition in terms of ARPGs these days, and even a tiny indie project must consider that, because you're fighting for that time. I would like to see this game do things a little differently, offer something fresh, as opposed to the same things found in AAA ARPGs, but at a smaller and pixelated scale.

6/10 Not terrible.
